title: 113_hr5837
content: The Act may be cited as the "African Descent Act of 2014". Congress finds that discrimination against people of African descent is a global challenge, with issues including exclusion, violence, and disparities in various sectors. It is crucial to address the lingering effects of slavery and colonialism hindering racial equality and recognition of contributions by people of African descent. The International Decade for People of African Descent, from January 1, 2015, to December 31, 2025, aims to address discrimination and disparities globally through coordinated strategies involving government, civil society, and the private sector. The State Department is amending the State Department Basic Authorities Act of 1956 to include a new section establishing the Office of Global African Descent Affairs. The State Department is establishing the Office of Global African Descent Affairs within the Department of State, headed by the Director and Special Advisor appointed by the Secretary. The Office will be supported by two senior Foreign Service officers and will advise the Secretary on activities and policies related to global African descent affairs. The Office of Global African Descent Affairs within the State Department advises the Secretary on human rights and the advancement of people of African descent internationally. It represents the United States in diplomatic matters related to the human rights of people of African descent and leads efforts to promote an international focus on this issue. The Office of Global African Descent Affairs leads diplomatic initiatives with other countries to promote racial equality globally. It manages a $3,000,000 fund for innovative solutions to combat racial discrimination and create opportunities for people of African descent. It also develops indicators for monitoring foreign policy assistance and directs resources to address protection and integration needs. The Office of Global African Descent Affairs works to address the needs of people of African descent in US policies and international programs, collaborating with the Race, Ethnicity, and Social Inclusion Unit. They compile an annual report on US government activities related to people of African descent. The Office of Global African Descent Affairs collaborates with committees in the Senate and House of Representatives to address the needs of people of African descent. The Foreign Assistance Act of 1961 is amended to include a new subsection on the status of people of African descent in annual human rights reports for various regions. The Foreign Assistance Act of 1961 is amended to include a new subsection requiring reports on the status of people of African descent in countries across the Americas, Europe, Asia, and the Middle East. The Foreign Assistance Act of 1961 is amended to include reports on people of African descent in various countries. The term 'people of African descent' is defined in the African Descent Act of 2014. $5,000,000 is authorized for the Secretary of State annually from 2015 to 2026 for this purpose. The Secretary of State is authorized to accept private contributions for the President Obama Fund for African Descent Affairs. SEC. 4. ACTIVITIES OF THE UNITED STATES AGENCY FOR INTERNATIONAL DEVELOPMENT. The Administrator of the United States Agency for International Development appoints a Senior Advisor on Global African Descent Affairs to advise on human rights and empowerment policies for people of African descent internationally. The Administrator of the United States Agency for International Development appoints a Senior Advisor on Global African Descent Affairs to develop a policy, strategy, and action plan in consultation with civil society, focusing on people of African descent. The Advisor also serves as a liaison to the Department of State's Office on Global African Descent Affairs and develops indicators for monitoring foreign assistance. $3,000,000 is authorized for each fiscal year from 2015 to 2026 for this purpose. SEC. 5. FUNDING. $8,000,000 is authorized annually from 2015 to 2026 for the implementation of this Act under the "Diplomatic and Consular Programs" budget. The Secretary of State must eliminate positions within the Department of State to offset the costs incurred by this Act. No additional funds are allowed for this purpose. SEC. 6. DEFINITIONS. The term "appropriate congressional committees" refers to specific committees in the Senate and House of Representatives. The term "people of African descent" includes individuals of African origin residing in various regions. The Director and Special Advisor to the Secretary on Global African Descent Affairs must provide briefings to congressional committees on the status of human rights and empowerment of people of African descent internationally, along with assessments of resources needed to fulfill the Act's purposes. SEC. 8. US POLICY TO PREVENT AND RESPOND TO DISCRIMINATION AND VIOLENCE AGAINST PEOPLE OF AFRICAN DESCENT. The Director and Special Advisor to the Secretary on Global African Descent Affairs must develop a US global strategy to empower, prevent, and respond to discrimination and violence against people of African descent within 180 days of the enactment of this Act. The strategy must be updated annually for 5 years and shared with congressional committees. Collaboration with relevant Federal agencies, civil society, and private sector organizations is required. This Act and its amendments will end on October 1, 2026.
